text: this is edward wong a correspondent in
the beijing bureau of the new york times
I recently traveled with dozens of
Chinese business people and other
journalists to get a glimpse of the
secretive authoritarian nation of North
Korea we were invited to be guinea pigs
on a trial run of its first-ever tourist
cruise we crossed the border from
northeast China to the Korean town of
Raja the ship had been built in North
Korea in 1972 it had most recently been
used as a cargo freighter this was no
Queen Elizabeth here's my room they
squeezed eight journalists in here
the dining facilities weren't quite
first-class they reminded me of military
bases I had seen in Iraq in the morning
we pulled into the harbor of Kumgang
sang a stunning tourist parked near the
South Korean border officials and North
Korean reporters were on hand to greet
us the park was started as a joint
venture between a North Korean
government and South Korean company but
the South Korean government ordered
their citizens to stop coming after a
South Korean tourist was shot dead
nearby a soldier in 2008 now the North
Koreans need other investors so that's
why the Chinese are here after the boat
our hotel felt like the ritz-carlton
North Korea is mired in poverty and
suffers from chronic food shortages but
not here there were more performances
and we were brought to the North Korean
version of a duty-free shop foreigners
have to pay in dollars or Chinese
renminbi North Korea's desperate for
foreign currency the next day before
going back to the boat we saw more of
the amazing scenery carved into this
rocker words in praise of the families
of North Korea's leaders the organizers
of the trip tonus they hope to invite
european tourists on the next cruise
they also say they want to get a bigger
boat finally we arrived back into Harbor
at Raj in
we're and it's the concrete pier when we
arrived everyone was eager to get off
the ship maybe the captain was even more
eager than us to get on shore
you
